parts.text: Hello my name is Alexandra and I'm going to have a conversation
with Alex caddy for visible light An Oral History Project at
the New York Public Library.
It is found in two thousand and fifteen
and this is being recorded in my home mountain town in New York
and. I ask.
If I.
Can tell you a bit about where you grew up. Sure I grew up in a suburban town in
New York is very Irish population. And me being Italian felt a little
bit out of place but you know it was a nice place
primarily upper middle class. And the
target of about fifteen thousand people.
Do.
You remember your first encounter or really sick our encounter with somebody who
had some kind of disability.
Yes there was a student in one of my classes in elementary school and I
believe he had cerebral palsy. But he always was
very well liked he had friends in school. And
he always seemed to be having a good time. I mean we all know how together.
How did that make you feel it was good to see that our
classmates accepted him and didn't treat him differently just because he had
a disability that made him.
Like act differently from us and we act differently in a physical way. But it didn't
change the fact that people still want to talk and they wanted to be friends with him so I
was happy to see that that's good.
So in high school you had friends thanking a transplant and
somebody who was going through something quite different but
you weren't put off in any way.
Why is that. Because I realize that everybody living myself
has certain struggles that we have to face in our lives and there's
nothing to say that one person's struggle is better or
worse more uncomfortable than someone else's It's just things that they have to deal with but
it doesn't make them a different person.
And then.
That friend introduced you to somebody else who had a transplant. Me
. And had me even become friends.
I remember that I think he introduced us on AM when he was
popular here so I find it funny how it's changed since then
but I remember we were talking maybe it was a snow day or something and we just kept talking online
and we just became friends that way and then I think the
first time we came we hung out was when he came to see one of the plays that I was working on.
Yasser so because it's a lovely
technology our friendship started
. Yeah exactly.
We've been friends for about seven years but it feels so much longer.
Maybe Haynes you never judged me.
You know I mean if you're paying for. Twenty five I
hate to judge you because I don't I never saw you any differently than I saw
anybody else.
I mean we're all people so I'm happy that our friendship started
so strong and it's lasted for this time and you're right it does feel longer because we've
been through so much high school college and other things and we've
seen so many many shows and they're done a lot
Do you ever feel uncomfortable. Or like you didn't know the right things to say to
me
. No I think I always
I've always known what to say. I mean if you just talk to your friends
that's just it. You just talk to your friends and sometimes it's hard to
think of what to say to people in general like if people are going through a bad break up or there's something
you know that they need help with Sometimes you don't know how to console them if you've never been
through it before but sometimes there's not much you can do other than just listen to them
and hear them out when they're stressed and be there for them if they if they need your
support.
Yes I agree.
Like you know here's a good example. When I was having gone to have
another surgery had that make you feel.
I was worried for you but I knew that you didn't you were
strong you are strong and that you are going to have a problem getting through it because you've gotten through
everything up until that point I was
Really scared with me I think a little bit but I didn't know I
think it's a different kind of scared because you don't know what it feels like to
be the person going their way. You can only see it from an outside ones
so you hope that everything is going to go well but it's not your
own. It's not your own experience
. So it's a little bit different but I think even though it wasn't your own experience
you lived it vicariously through me and yes
for sure I had that you know I remember very I think you were see that
before he went you know what rightly said to you or your kind of nervous that your
mom was like trying to calm you down or whatever and I just remember thinking I couldn't imagine
what I would be like I can't be doing the same thing. Freaking out like oh my gosh I don't know if I can
do this but. Yeah I don't know I just
. Think that one of the only kind of put it in perspective for me because I figured I'd be acting the
same way you are so annoying.
OK. So you know I never really thought of this
this way but it. I guess you know for our friendship to continue
you had to come to terms with the fact that. You know. I
am disabled I have medical stuff and this was kind of my existence
We think that he feels I mean he didn't make me
feel anything different we still do things that
everybody else to do is to friends it's just that maybe I'll be the one driving all the time and you may not
be but you know that's OK. We work around the things that you might have a little bit
more difficulty doing and we get we do whatever we want to do anyway.
Yes You know this too sometimes you have to be creative. Yeah.
I always felt that you had empathy towards me.
I've seen you have had it with this are you aware I guess it
is sometimes twelve eleven where I think it's because. Like I said
before we all have struggles that we're dealing with and I know that I have my own
personal things that I am trying to work through sometimes still and trying to work through. So
even if I'm not going through the same thing as someone else you have something completely different but I've never had to deal with.
I understand that it might be tough for that person and that maybe they need
someone to to be their friend and to listen to them and
sometimes that listening it helps it helps for people to vent holes for people to
to know that someone does care even if they don't have that same exact
experience.
Yes.
Give all that you know about my medical condition. What
has surprised you about me
. I think you are. Resiliency. When there's a
problem the way that you're able to you're able to go to the
doctor and and get shots and whatnot it doesn't faze you
. But also just the way they never let it stop you from doing what you want and then you work
on your ceramics and I think that's really cool. So not a lot of people do that. You never let it stop you from
being creative in trying to work in a theater. You graduated college.
Like all these things that people I think don't really realize that with a
disability are one hundred percent capable of doing one hundred percent capable of doing and I
think that before we were friends I never really thought about it.
But then after seeing what you can do I realized like anybody can do anything
you can you really can.
Are you able to learn from somebody who has to do things so differently from yourself
Yes I think as a teacher. Which is what I do
that you have to be open to learning to how learning how other
people do things because you can you can see a lot
of different perspectives and maybe it'll give you some idea on how to manage something in
your own life. Maybe a thing you never you know what you never thought of before maybe you'll see a new perspective you
never thought of before. So. We have to we have to learn from others otherwise we would
be closed off and we wouldn't really go anywhere as individuals or as a society
I think.
You know life in general as a whole. Planning ahead. Absolutely I
believe that we're learning from the time we're born until the day we die. Yes.
He has not let me change your perspective on
disability in any particular way.
I guess any perceptions you had before knowing
in the years that you have known me.
Yeah I think that like I was saying a couple minutes ago that I never
really thought about people with disabilities. Oh you
know very explicitly. Except maybe that one classmate that I
know that I was with. But he doesn't let anything stop him from doing
anything and when I saw him making friends and running around the track with the rest of us
you know it's a lot harder for him I said or realize that anybody drinking and then when
we became friends I really question it I didn't really think that maybe there were things
that you couldn't do or or weren't capable of doing because really you don't let things
get you down. So I guess I saw that disability maybe in
these things more difficult in one way but it doesn't stop people from being who they are
and getting things done that they want to do.
You know just sometimes I may have to do it is a different way just doesn't mean I can't
exactly.
Just I have to find a way.
Do you ever feel compelled to help somebody with an obvious disability. Because
you know me.
Yes and I don't know if it's because I know you already just by my
nature but one of my jobs we have a lot we have patrons that come into the
theater and sometimes they're in wheelchairs or walkers or canes
and you know I it's just knowing that they need someone to
to maybe clear the path for them and get them down to their stage level seeing it little
things and they get it they really do appreciate it when someone understands that maybe they need a little
bit of extra help. And then as a teacher you see students who have
some you know I P's.
And again it's just knowing that having some of them.
What kind of modifications they need in just helping them and they really appreciate you can see how how
well do you want to take the time out to to make the appropriate modifications
so just giving someone a little extra hands goes a long way. So do you
. Feel I notice that you actually go out of your way to tell
people that you know have an obvious disability
I.E. I don't really consider it going out of my way I would just consider it being
a good person doing the doing the right thing and I think going out of your way implies
that it's a bother to bother burden which should be every we should just help each
other that's the way it's supposed to be and then maybe I said that way and
please and maybe.
Why don't you go out of your way. You know just you have that whole that
feeling that you want to help more.
Oh yes I think so because I don't want to be I want to make
someone's day joy while I want someone to realize that there
are good people out there was one time living people will turn a blind eye and I definitely don't want to
be that person because hey we're all people and you never know what's going to happen to you in
your life and you want to let someone else enjoy themselves and
you want them to have a good experience because you know so do the same for you
so much and.
You know. What disability they they truly know when you're
being sincere or you're faking it you know you've always been sincere
thank you. I think also you're OK to help
other people in this case of no meat you feel like an insider
Yes and you get you get it you just get it.
Yeah because even those people that have different abilities it's just knowing that sometimes you have
to get over it.
So if you have personal experiences with
people who have had difficult journeys
what would you want what would you say on their behalf to the world outside of the
civility and I would say don't judge.
And that might sound really obvious but it's true because
they just fear that a lot of people have is the judgment of others
. And what will people say and what are they going to think and that's really a
paralyzing fear for a lot of people that I've seen but the strongest people are the ones
that say you know what people are going to judge me and I can't do anything about it so I'm just going to do what I
need to do and move on. But the thing is it's sad that it
has to be like that and it's sad that people will always judge
I should say will be judged hopefully it'll change but people do judge so harshly.
So I think my biggest message to the people who
don't necessarily deal with disability is. I
don't I don't judge really. Because you don't know how much you can you can
hurt someone without even realizing it.
And Alex for my final question. Any words of wisdom
I would say try as as a person in
society just try to learn from others and
hear other people's stories and hear their experiences because that will give
you such a good well rounded view of
what life is like for not only yourself the people that you're close to but you learn
so many other things and maybe from learning something else you'll get to meet new people and make new
friends that you never thought you would have. For I know that from working in search in different
jobs and and taking on different interests I met friends from all different walks
and I think that that's so interesting and so fun because
life isn't black and white there are so many different things in between
. So you should try to learn as much as you can as
I tend to say I would agree. I don't really know about the black and
white.
That's true. Yeah. So that's what I would say is that
the best thing to do and just as a general thing you know it's
good in.
That it is the end of our conversation. Thank you so much. Alex thanks for having
me.
